subject: Re: Passing Arguments to an ANT Buildfile
msgSnippet: Yes, surely its feasible, I ve already thought of it... the problem is that I begin to depend upon a shell file, what in final analysis makes me lose the best
messageBody:
Yes, surely its feasible, I've already thought of it... the problem
is that I begin to depend upon a shell file, what in final analysis
makes me lose the best profit of ant, that is to be completely shell-
independent... thanks, George, but if I need to put some logic on
shell files, guys here that resist on quitting makefiles will
certainly come with something like: "but what the hell was this Ant
created for?" :)

Leonardo

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, ghmck@s... wrote:
> I see your point.
>
> My shell skills are quite low (in other words, I can't describe how
to do it ), but you should be able to conditionalize at that level
something like:
> if $2=""
> then ant $1
> else ant -Dtestfile="$2" $1
>
> and keep the other guys happy.
>
> I suggest that route rather than trying contortions in the
build.xml itself.
>
> The Hatcher & Loughran book has a similar idiom that is a standard
part of our build, and is really handy when doing new code.
>
> George
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: Leonardo Abreu de Barros <leobarros@e...>
> Date: Monday, July 7, 2003 12:15 pm
> Subject: [junit] Re: Passing Arguments to an ANT Buildfile
>
> > Hello guys,
> >
> > I really appreciate and I'd like to thank all of you for your
> > comments about my question. There were some questions about why
> > I'm
> > needing that functionality, so let me explain the whole case:
> >
> > I have a requirement, surely pretty common, of using ant in two
> > different ways:
> > 1) ant ---> should run all my suite of automatic tests
> > 2) ant <name of testfile> ---> should run only a specific test
> >
> > This way, my first idea was to use a property "testfile" with a
> > default value, that could be overriden by using a "-Dtestfile"
> > flag.
> >
> > But there is another detail here: everybody in the company is
used
> > to
> > makefiles, which they activate by typing "build". In order to
> > maintain this experience, I created a shell file which just calls
> > ant, sending a parameter, this way:
> > ant $1
> >
> > In order to use the flag, I thought of rewriting the shell file
> > like
> > this:
> > ant -Dtestfile="$2" $1
> >
> > which works, but as the flag is always set, even if I don't send
> > any
> > parameter to the build command, the property becames blank.
> >
> > That's why I posted the question, ok? But I think to preserve
> > this "build" alias is not worth the cost of treating the blank
> > case,
> > so I guess I should convince the other guys to use "ant" and
> > that's
> > it.
> >
> > Thanks again,
> > Leonardo Barros
> >
> >
> > --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Michael Holly" <mholly@t...> wrote:
> > > I don't know if this helps or if read the thread correctly, but
> > could he
> > > setup a ant property with his default value and if he wants to
> > override it
> > > just pass in the new
> > > value on the command line. I use this method to substitute
> > different
> > > properties/config files for the server that I am building. So
> > "ant
> > all"
> > > will build and test on my development box where as "ant all -
> > Dserver=test"
> > > will build and test on my test server. "server" corresponds to
a
> > section of
> > > the path where the config files are stored. So to utilize the
> > property I
> > > have the following in my ant script.
> > >
> > > <copy todir = "${app.build.home}/WEB-INF">
> > > <fileset dir="${source.home}/WEB-INF/${server}">
> > > <include name = "**/web.xml"/>
> > > </fileset>
> > > </copy>
> > >
> > > This really does not require any "if" logic as a value set in
> > the
> > command
> > > line overrides any internally set properties. This technique
is
> > explained
> > > in "Ant The Definitive Guide" by Tilly & Burke page 256
Appendix
> > B
> > Ant
> > > Solutions.
> > >
> > > I have probably misunderstood and said to much...
> > >
> > > Michael
> > >
> > > "Pain makes life apparent"
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > > -----Original Message-----
> > > From: Jason Rogers [jacaetevha@f...]
> > > Sent: Monday, July 07, 2003 10:26 AM
> > > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > > Subject: RE: [junit] Passing Arguments to an ANT Buildfile
> > >
> > >
> > > But what he was getting at (for what reason I don't know) was
> > that
> > if he
> > > set it on the commandline as an empty string he wanted to
> > override
> > that
> > > with the default value. The original poster has not yet
> > responded
> > to
> > > any of these responses, but I ask again, why would you ever
want
> > that
> > > functionality?
> > >
> > > =jason
> > >
> > > On Mon, 2003-07-07 at 10:02, Ilja Preuss wrote:
> > > > Timothy Wall wrote:
> > > > > Here's one option, others are probably available using "if"
and
> > > > > "condition":
> > > > >
> > > > > <target name="default-value" unless="testfile">
> > > > > <property name="testfile" value="default-value"/>
> > > > > </target>
> > > >
> > > > That's unnecessarily complicated. Simply use
> > > >
> > > > <property name="testfile" value="default-value"/>
> > > >
> > > > Properties can't be overridden, so if it is already set (for
> > example
> > > > from the command line), it still would have the original
value.
> > > >
> > > > Regards, Ilja
